summary.name: AirPods
summary.description: This Manifest traces the origins of Apple's AirPods. AirPods are Apple's wireless headphones that continue to dominate their market.

overview.name: TSMC (Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company)- Taiwan Factory
overview.description: TSMC builds Apple H2 chips, which are used in AirPods. Despite the US and China's efforts to increase chip production outside of Taiwan, the world remains dependent on TSMC's production supply. Chips for AirPods are likely made in Taiwan at TSMC's factory.

location.address: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company 15A wafer plant: (Fab 15A)No. 1號, Keya 6th Rd, Daya District, Taichung City, Taiwan 428

overview.name: TSMC- Phoenix, AZ Factory
overview.description: In 2022, TSMC announced plans to open a factory in Phoenix, AZ. Chips for AirPods will likely be made in this factory in the future. "The upgraded plan is the latest sign of how geopolitical concerns are causing companies and governments to modify longtime strategies, countering historical trends that led companies to shift most semiconductor manufacturing to Asia. It also underscores the widening recognition of the importance of chips and new technologies for producing them, which add calculating power to consumer gadgets, cars and military equipment such as missiles and drones." (Kellen Browning, New York Times)

overview.name: Cobalt Smelters and Refiners
overview.description: Cobalt is used in lithium-ion batteries, which power AirPods. Most of Apple's smelters and refiners are located in mainland China with others in Finland and Belgium. Smelters and refiners alter Cobalt from its raw form so it can be used in batteries. Cobalt is a conflict mineral, and its sourcing can be problematic (see below).

location.address: Ganzhou Yihao Youmei Ke Industry Company Ltd: China, Jiangxi, Ganzhou, Zhanggong District, 105国道 邮政编码: 341007

overview.name: Cobalt Sourcing in the DRC
overview.description: The Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) contains nearly half the world's cobalt reserves, holding four million metric tons of the Earth's 8.3 million metric tons. Apple does not source cobalt directly from DRC, but many of its smelters and refineries do. Apple claims that its suppliers undergo third party audits and "human rights due diligence" to improve conditions. Miners in the DRC are subject to hazardous working conditions, little pay, and child labor abuses. Some believe that big tech companies and foreign governments are exploiting the DRC for its resources to build wealth outside of the country.

location.address: Kolwezi Mine (Kolwezi Pit), Kolwezi, Kolwezi mining district, Lualaba, DR Congo

overview.name: Lithium Smelters and Refiners
overview.description: Lithium is "one of the most [valuable components] of high energy-density rechargeable lithium-ion batteries" (Goonan). Lithium-ion batteries are used in AirPods and numerous other Apple devices. All of Apple's lithium smelters and refiners are located in mainland China.

location.address: Haimen, Jiangsu, China- This is the location of General Lithium, one of Apple's many lithium suppliers.

overview.name: Lithium Sourcing
overview.description: Lithium is found throughout the world in the following countries in order of largest to smallest supply: Chile, Australia, Argentina, China, United States, Canada, Zimbabwe, Brazil, and Portugal. Often,"faraway [lithium mining] companies [profit] from mineral riches while the communities that own the land struggle to pay for sewage systems, drinking water and heat for schools" (Jing and Fernandez, Washington Post). Lithium mining companies extract millions of dollars from indigenous lands by harming local environments and using excessive amounts of local water supplies which in turn causes water shortages for those who live in the area. This has caused strain among local communities, violation of human rights in labor practices, and excessive environmental harm. The wealth held in the mines is exported to foreign markets, giving little or no benefit to those who are most hurt by the mines.

location.address: Salar de Atacama, San Pedro de Atacama, Antofagasta, Chile

overview.name: Tungsten
overview.description: Apple's tungsten smelters and refiners are located throughout the world, with most based in mainland China. Tungsten is one of the extremely strong and heat-resistent, and also has magnetic qualities that contribute to its electric field. Although it was difficult to find the specific use of Tungsten in AirPods, it may be a part of the AirPods' engine, inner wiring system, heat regulation mechanisms, or charging capabilites.

location.address:
Chenzhou Diamond Tungsten Products Co.,Ltd.
郴州钻石钨制品有限责任公司, Q5W8+XR7, Suxian District, Chenzhou, Hunan, China, 423037

overview.name: Tungsten Sourcing
overview.description: The largest concentrations of Tungsten are found in the following countries, in order from most to least: China, Vietnam, Russia, Bolivia, Rwanda, Austria, Spain, and Portugal. Tungsten is a conflict mineral, as some of the world's Tungsten comes from the DRC. Tungsten mines are "sometimes controlled by armed groups to finance the ongoing conflict in the DRC and adjoining countries, both indirectly and directly" (Ion).

location.address: Laikeng tungsten mine, Helong orefield, Gan Co., Ganzhou, Jiangxi, China

overview.name: Tin Smelters and Refiners
overview.description: Tin smelting and refining is the conversion of identifiable materials into a common product for all downstream consumers. 100% of the Tin smelters and refiners have completed a Third-Party Audit.

overview.name: Tin Sourcing
overview.description: Since 2015, Apple has provided funding to the International Tin Association’s International Tin Supply Chain Initiative’s (“ITSCI”) whistleblowing mechanism in the DRC.

location.address: Unit 3, Curo Park Frogmore St Albans AL2 2DD United Kingdom

overview.name: Tantalum Smelters and Refiners
overview.description: Tantalum smelting and refining is the conversion of identifiable materials into a common product for all downstream consumers. 100% of the tantalum smelters and refiners have completed a Third-Party Audit.

overview.name: Tantalum Sourcing
overview.description: As of December 2014, Rwanda disclosed that a year prior, it had dramatically boosted tantalum exports to become the world's largest exporter. They then ship out to foreign smelters, mostly in Mainland China, some 2,460 tons, 28 percent of the global total of around 8,800 tons.

overview.name: Gold Smelters and Refiners
overview.description: Gold (3TG) smelting and refining is the conversion of materials into a common product for all downstream consumers. 100% of the gold smelters and refiners have completed a Third-Party Audit. The smelter/refiner is believed to process at least some 3TG from recycled or scrap sources.

overview.name: Gold Sourcing
overview.description: In Fall of 2019, Salmon Gold entered Apple's supply chain. Salmon Gold is an organization that is connecting local placer miners, environmentalists and government agencies in order to course correct the damage done from historic mining in the Alaska-Yukon region.

overview.name: Nickel
overview.description: Airpods contain small amounts of nickel, which falls below the strict nickel restrictions set by European REACH regulation. While nickel exposure is unlikely, consumers should be aware of the possibility in case they are susceptible to nickel related reactions.

overview.name: Acrylates
overview.description: Airpods, and most Apple products contain trace amounts of acrylates from adhesives. Acrylates are found in many products that come in contact with the skin, such as adhesive bandages. Acrylates result from the esterification of acrylic acids. Acrylates are produced when acrylic acid reacts with an alcohol to produce water as a by-product.

overview.name: Apple's Environment Reports and Recycling Efforts
overview.description: Apple has developed programs to use recycled tungsten, lessen packaging waste, reduce its carbon footprint, make devices more durable or "oops-resistant", and use 100% recylced gold, tin, and rare earth minerals in its devices, which the company plans to expand. Apple provides comprehensive environmental reports for most of its items (as seen in the "apple.com/environment" source listed in this row). At the time of investigation Apple had specific environmental reports for a wide range of its products including iPhones, iPads, various computers, and other Apple products. However, there was no environmental report specific to AirPods. This is interesting, as the company almost definitely has this information but is not making it easily accessible. A report may be forthcoming or I may have missed the document, but it seems possible Apple may be trying to lessen reporting on the true environmental impact of AirPods. Attached is an image of one of Apple's Daisy robots, which disassembles old iPhones to capture used materials for use in new devices.
